title: Conditionals Type 1 or Type 2 - 1
instructions: Complete the sentences to make type 1 or type 2 conditional sentences.

sentence: If I had more time, I
explain: Corr: would visit. There's past tense in the if-part, so we need 'would' here.

sentence: They will forgive you if you
explain: Corr: say. There's 'will' in the main clause, so it's type 1 conditional, and so we need present simple in the if-clause.

sentence: you react if your boss wanted to fire you?
explain: Corr: would. It's type 2 because there's past in the if-clause, so we need 'would' in the main clause.

sentence: (be) your birthday, we will celebrate it.
explain: Corr: is. There's 'will' in the main clause so it's type 1 conditional, so we need present simple in the if-clause.

sentence: we stay at home if it rains?
explain: Corr: Will. There's present tense in the if-clause, so it's type 1 conditional and we need 'will' in the main clause.

sentence: If Sean didn't want to work, I
explain: Corr: would fire. There's past tense in the if-clause, so it's type 2 conditional, so we need 'would' in the main clause.

sentence: (celebrate) if my son wanted to come back from abroad.
explain: Corr: would be. It's type 2 conditional because there is past in the if-clause, so we need 'would' in the main clause.
Corr: would celebrate. It's type 2 conditional because there is past in the if-clause, so we need 'would' in the main clause.

sentence: (be) grateful to him if he put me in the right direction.
explain: Corr: would be. There's past tense in the if-clause. (It would be 'puts' if it was present tense.) So we need 'would' in the main clause.

sentence: If you don't play attention, you
explain: Corr: will fail. There's present tense in the if-clause, so we need 'will' in the main clause.
Corr: were. There's 'would' in the main clause, so it's type 2 conditional and we need past tense in the if clause. Here we need 'were' in the 'if I were you' fixed phrase.
